channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Coronavirus in America: The Year Ahead
item.description: There will be no quick return to our previous lives, according to nearly two dozen experts. But there is hope for managing the scourge now and in the long term.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health worker checking her protective equipment in a mirror in Central Park in New York.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: U.S. States Call for More Testing; White House Pushes Back
item.description: New York and New Jersey say they can’t reopen their economies without wider testing for the virus. Civil rights organizers are finding new ways to organize during the lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus World News Updates
item.description: A plane with 84 tons of urgently needed protective medical gear expected to arrive from Turkey in Britain was delayed, the U.K. government said.
item.media:description: Visitors to the presidential palace in Kabul, Afghanistan, are being sprayed with disinfectant and subjected to temperature checks.

item.title: Coronavirus in N.Y. Live Updates: De Blasio to Trump
item.description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio have continued to plead for President Trump’s help on test kits and the economy.

item.title: An Overlooked, Possibly Fatal Coronavirus Crisis: A Dire Need for Kidney Dialysis
item.description: Ventilators aren’t the only machines in intensive care units that are in short supply. Doctors have been confronting an unexpected rise in patients with failing kidneys.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson, Sheri Fink, Nicholas Kulish and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ms. Figueroa of Brooklyn Hospital Center, treating a patient who had developed acute kidney injury.

item.title: Is the Virus on My Clothes? My Shoes? My Hair? My Newspaper?
item.description: We asked the experts to answer questions about all the places coronavirus lurks (or doesn’t). You’ll feel better after reading this.
item.dc:creator: Tara Parker-Pope

item.title: Full Coronavirus Coverage
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: America’s Biggest Cities Were Already Losing Their Allure. What Happens Next?
item.description: The urge among some residents to leave because of the coronavirus may be temporary. But it follows a deeper, more powerful demographic trend.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters wait for the J train at Broadway Junction in East New York, Brooklyn on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘Something Is Going to Explode’: When Coronavirus Strikes a Prison
item.description: An oral history of the first fatal outbreak in the federal prison system, in Oakdale, La.
item.dc:creator: Janet Reitman
item.media:credit: William Widmer/Redux, for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign for the Federal Correctional Complex in Oakdale, La.

item.title: Coronavirus Turns School Cafeterias into Soup Kitchens
item.description: Many school cafeterias are now operating more like community soup kitchens, even though the federal school meals program won’t reimburse districts for meals served to struggling adults.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and Lola Fadulu
item.media:description: Workers preparing lunch bags at Sinclair Lane Elementary School in Baltimore.

item.title: No Fight Over Red Ink Now, but Virus Spending Will Force Tough Choices
item.description: The surge of deficit spending to “never-before-seen levels” is viewed as necessary, but dangerous for the future.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
item.media:description: Senator Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania, says that trying to fight the deficit with a tax hike “will crater the economy and postpone the recovery for I don’t know long.’’

item.title: C.D.C. Labs Were Contaminated, Delaying Coronavirus Testing, Officials Say
item.description: Fallout from the agency’s failed rollout of national coronavirus kits two months ago continues to haunt U.S. efforts to combat the spread of the highly infectious virus.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Kaplan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention headquarters in Atlanta.

item.title: Trump Has Begun His Corona Campaign. We Don’t Have to Play Along.
item.description: The coronavirus story isn’t about the president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Smith
item.media:description: President Trump during a coronavirus briefing at the White House last week.

item.title: In ESPN's 'The Last Dance' Documentary, Michael Jordan and the Bulls Still Dominate
item.description: ESPN’s new 10-part documentary doesn’t ask Big Questions. But it does go big on a team whose personalities and feats warrant just this sort of excess.
item.dc:creator: Wesley Morris
item.media:description: Michael Jordan’s brilliance on the court rendered him impervious to overstatement. The new 10-part ESPN documentary “The Last Dance” reminds viewers why.

item.title: The Coronavirus Doesn’t Care When Sports Come Back
item.description: The prolonged shutdown of the sports world is taking a huge financial toll. And comeback plans all have a pesky hurdle — public health.
item.dc:creator: Joe Drape, Ken Belson and Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ballparks around the country, like Chase Field in Arizona, have been empty as baseball and government officials have tried to think of ways to bring sports back.

item.title: As Bolsonaro Keeps Amazon Vows, Brazil’s Indigenous Fear ‘Ethnocide’
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro is moving aggressively to open up the Amazon rainforest to commercial development, posing an existential threat to the tribes living there.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Uru Eu Wau Wau tribe, clockwise from top left; Tapé, Oatuto, Tebu, Poajup, Mandeí and Felipe. All share the tribe’s name as a family name.

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.description: A mom’s last words to her daughter. What a wedding dress means. How New Yorkers talk. 52 Places, virtually. And more.
item.dc:creator: Kaly Soto

item.title: Coronavirus, Testing, Fiona Apple: Your Weekend Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker

item.title: The Sunday Read: The Woman Who Might Find Us Another Earth
item.description: The star-crossed life of Sara Seager, an astrophysicist obsessed with discovering the possibility of other life in the universe.
item.media:description: Sara Seager is a tenured professor of physics and of planetary science, certified a “genius” by the MacArthur Foundation in 2013. Her area of expertise is the relatively new field of exoplanets: planets that orbit stars other than our sun.

item.title: Sign Up: ‘Watching’
item.description: Get recommendations on the best TV shows and movies to watch.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Sign Up: ‘Coronavirus Briefing’
item.description: An informed guide to the global outbreak.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Bernie Sanders: The Foundations of American Society Are Failing Us
item.description: The unequal impact of the pandemic and economic collapse are forcing us to rethink the assumptions of our system.
item.dc:creator: Bernie Sanders
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Trump Is Asking Us to Play Russian Roulette With Our Lives
item.description: Are we really going to bet that we can go back to life as normal without proper coronavirus tracking in place?
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:description: President Trump in the White House briefing room on Thursday.

item.title: Can Gavin Newsom Lead California Through the Coronavirus Pandemic?
item.description: The governor has delivered fanfare. Now he must lead the state through the calamities of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Pawel
item.media:description: Gavin Newsom spoke about what it would take to lift coronavirus restrictions in California last week.

item.title: ‘Woe Is You,’ White People Say. What We Need Is a Remedy.
item.description: Think about why the virus is poised to rip through black neighborhoods like mine.
item.dc:creator: Jeremiah Bey Ellison
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremiah Ellison, a member of the Minneapolis City Council, fears for his neighborhood.

item.title: The Coronavirus Has Laid Bare the Inequality of America's Health Care
item.description: Our system takes from the poor and working class to generate wealth for the already wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Anne Case and Angus Deaton

item.title: For My Mother’s FaceTime Burial, Lipstick and Howling Winds
item.description: In Jewish tradition the body must be buried within 24 hours. I fight with myself about whether to travel to Cleveland.
item.dc:creator: Jill Bialosky
item.media:description: A family in Connecticut sitting shiva remotely for an elderly relative who died of heart failure last week.

item.title: A Decade After Deepwater Horizon
item.description: Rolling back regulations ignores the central lessons from the country’s largest oil spill.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Missing Barack Obama's Voice
item.description: Many young progressives, conflicted about the former president’s legacy, welcomed his re-emergence this week.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith

item.title: Trump and His Allies Are Worried About More Than November
item.description: The temporary imposition of popular relief programs in response to the coronavirus makes Republicans nervous.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: President Trump discusses small business relief at the White House last week.

item.title: A 425-Pound Tiger Living in a Harlem Apartment? Yes, It Happened
item.description: Before “Tiger King,” there was New York’s infamous Tiger Man.
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon
item.media:credit: John Roca/NY Daily News Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: After the police shot him with a tranquilizer dart, Ming the tiger lunged at the window.

item.title: A Beloved Bar Owner Was Skeptical About the Virus. Then He Took a Cruise.
item.description: Joe Joyce oversaw JJ Bubbles, a welcoming tavern in a conservative corner of Brooklyn, for 43 years until he died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:description: Joe Joyce, left, the owner of JJ Bubbles, a popular neighborhood bar in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, with his family in the 1980s.

item.title: Coronavirus and Booking Travel: Considering the Risk
item.description: Inexpensive deals abound, and coupled with newly relaxed change and cancellation policies, some travelers are seeing little to no risk in pointing, clicking and purchasing.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Firshein

item.title: Multiple Victims in Nova Scotia Shooting, Police Say
item.description: The authorities identified the gunman as Gabriel Wortman, 51, who was taken into custody after a manhunt on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: 2 Georgia High Schoolers Posted Racist Video, Officials Say
item.description: The two are “no longer students” in the Carrollton, Ga., district, the superintendent said. Their video, posted on TikTok on Thursday, has been viewed millions of times across social media platforms.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla

item.title: Pharmacist Arrested in Plot to Firebomb a Rival to Sell More Drugs on the Dark Web
item.description: Hyrum T. Wilson of Auburn, Neb., conspired with a drug dealer to rob, then destroy a competitor’s pharmacy, according to federal prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer

item.title: Coronavirus Halts Another U.K. Ritual: Birthday Gun Salute for Queen
item.description: Buckingham Palace said the queen had also instructed that flags not be flown in her honor unless it was done while observing social distancing.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II talked about the coronavirus in a rare televised address this month.

item.title: Doctor Charged With Fraud After U.S. Says He Sold Treatment as ‘100 Percent’ Cure for Covid-19
item.description: A lawyer for Dr. Jennings Ryan Staley of California said his client believed he was helping people.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: Dr. Jennings Ryan Staley, 44, was charged with mail fraud on Thursday.

item.title: That Face Shield Might Have Been Made in a Party Space
item.description: A chic loft in the meatpacking district has reinvented itself as a factory for personal protective equipment.
item.dc:creator: Jane Margolies
item.media:description: Vladislava Bulatnikova stapling elastic to face shields on an assembly line at Consortium, a company that has converted a loft in the meatpacking district into a factory for personal protective equipment.

item.title: When Coronavirus Care Gets Lost in Translation
item.description: Medical interpreters must now work remotely, multiplying the challenges for front-line doctors and non-English-speaking patients.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cindarella Lee, a Cantonese interpreter for Sutter Health in San Francisco. Many hospitals have barred visitors, and some patients that Ms. Lee works with are elderly and “don’t understand why their loved ones don’t visit them,” she said.

item.title: Jobless Claims by Uber and Lyft Drivers Revive Fight Over Labor Status
item.description: California’s move to aid gig workers may break federal rules. But the state said it had few options after the ride-hailing companies resisted other benefits.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:description: A caravan protest outside a state office in Los Angeles on Thursday pressed for California to enforce a statute, challenged by Uber and Lyft, designating their drivers as employees.

item.title: Oklahoma City Bombing: City Marks 25 Years Since America's Deadliest Homegrown Attack
item.description: On the anniversary of the attack that killed 168 people, there is concern that the national memory is fading even as the violent ideology that inspired Timothy McVeigh spreads.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nick Oxford for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Oklahoma City National Memorial. The coronavirus outbreak forced the cancellation of most events marking the anniversary of the attack.

item.title: Yes, Even Introverts Can Be Lonely Right Now
item.description: Introverts crave connection, too — we just need more boundaries.
item.dc:creator: Adam Grant

item.title: The Difference Between Copyrights, Trademarks and Patents
item.description: Whether you’re an inventor, a writer or an artist, you need to know what these each mean — and which you need to protect your work.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Webb

item.title: Roommates or Partner Getting on Your Nerves? Read This
item.description: Talk about things early and often so they don’t boil over.
item.dc:creator: Anna Goldfarb

item.title: Eating Is Weird Now. Here’s How to (Kind of) Get Back to Normal.
item.description: If the coronavirus has busted your diet — and you’ve busted out the fat pants — here are some tips to get back on track.
item.dc:creator: Tim Herrera

item.title: Learn to Argue Productively
item.description: Arguments don’t have to be heated, explosive moments. As long as everyone’s in good faith, everyone can learn from one another.
item.dc:creator: Harry Guinness

item.title: Their Ring Bearer Was a Bear
item.description: Rita Janecek and Joseph Schaar, both animal lovers, had to call off a much-anticipated Alaskan wedding. Their new venue was about 5,000 miles away, at an animal sanctuary in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Vincent M. Mallozzi

item.title: How a Respiratory Therapist, Working ‘Code to Code,’ Spends His Sundays
item.description: What strikes David Van De Carr is the kindness of his hospital colleagues. ‘We say ‘I love you’ a lot more now.’
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Elizabeth D. Herman for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Van De Carr often gets to the hospital an hour before his shift starts to clear his mind.

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Shut My Doors’: Businesses Find Ways to Survive
item.description: Faced with closings and plunging sales while more Americans lose their jobs, entrepreneurs are becoming more nimble.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sullivan
item.media:credit: José Jiménez-Tirado for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Kapon, chairman of the wine merchant Acker, led a tasting on Zoom from his home in San Juan, P.R.

item.title: More Melty Cheese
item.description: Indulge in small ways, with a creamy, cheesy potato gratin, or choose something bright like salmon with peas and radishes.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Julia Gartland for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Michelle Gatton.
item.media:description: Mark Bittman’s gratin.

item.title: 12 Family-Friendly Nature Documentaries
item.description: “March of the Penguins,” “Monkey Kingdom” and more illuminate the wonders of our planet from the safety of your couch.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias
item.media:description: Jane Goodall as seen in “Jane,” a documentary directed by Brett Morgen.

item.title: Your 5-Year-Old
item.description: Though she might be the baby of the family, you have a big kid now. Your child is like a curious scientist, exploring and questioning the world around her. She has likely been inundating you with questions about “why” and “how.” Their curious minds make 5-year-olds great problem solvers and typically ready to learn as they enter kindergarten. At 5 years old, children can create entire fantasy worlds through their imaginative and dramatic play.
item.dc:creator: Nia Heard-Garris, M.D.

item.title: Why the Big Bang Produced Something Rather Than Nothing
item.description: How did matter gain the edge over antimatter in the early universe? Maybe, just maybe, neutrinos.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Kamioka Observatory, Institute for Cosmic Ray Research, University of Tokyo
item.media:description: The Super-Kamiokande Neutrino Observatory, located more than 3,000 feet below Mount Ikeno near the city of Hida, Japan.

item.title: Your Kids Don’t Have to Inherit Your Body-Image Issues
item.description: Parents who struggle with food and self-image can inadvertently pass along unhealthy behaviors. Here’s how to avoid it.
item.dc:creator: Virginia Sole-Smith
item.media:credit: Molly Matalon for The New York Times

item.title: Stay 6 Feet Apart, We’re Told. But How Far Can Air Carry Coronavirus?
item.description: Most of the big droplets travel a mere six feet. The role of tiny aerosols is the “trillion-dollar question.”
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh, James Gorman and Kenneth Chang
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A sign on the Coney Island boardwalk in Brooklyn advised visitors to keep a distance of at least six feet from each other, but some experts say that might not be enough.

item.title: Try Tiles
item.description: Our soothing matching game may help you de-stress.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Crossword, Vertex and More
item.description: Solve the daily puzzle edited by Will Shortz, or try out other games like the Mini and Letter Boxed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Try Spelling Bee
item.description: Puzzle throughout the day to see how many words you can find.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
